Table of Contents

Name

ec2-sync-users -- create user accounts from the running system to a given EC2 instance

Synopsis

ec2-sync-users [-hv] -i instance user [...]

Description

The ec2-sync-users tool will create accounts for the given users on the given EC2 instance in sync with the system it is running on. That is, for each user given on the command-line, ec2-sync-users will extract all login information (the uid, gid, gecos, and shell) from the running system and then create the same account on the given EC2 instance with these values.

Options

ec2-sync-users accepts the following command-line flags:

-h
Print a usage statement and exit.

-i instance
Use the given EC2 instance.

-v
Be verbose.

Details

ec2-sync-users takes as input an EC2 instance name (such as i-dd18eeb6") and a list of usernames. For each user, the uid, gid, gecos and shell are determined from the running system. Once the instance is determined to be running, ec2-sync-users will create all user accounts on the instance using precisely these parameters. If a user with the given username already exists on the remote instance, then ec2-sync-users will not perform any changes to the account information.

If a local user has a file named aws.pub in their ~/.ssh directory, ec2-sync-users will append it on the remote instance to that user's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file.

Output

Unless the -v flag is given, no output is generated unless an error occurs. Otherwise, ec2-sync-users may print out some useful information about what steps it is currently performing.

Any errors encountered cause a meaningful error message to be printed to STDERR.

Exit Status

The ec2-sync-users will exit with a return status of 0 under normal circumstances. If an error occurred, ec2-sync-users will exit with a value >0.

Examples

The following examples illustrate common usage of this tool.

ec2-sync-users -i i-dd18eeb6 jschauma bloom djd

See Also

ldapsearch(1) , finger(1) , id(1) , getpwent(3) , useradd(8)

History

ec2-sync-users was originally assigned by Jan Schaumann <jschauma@stevens.edu> as a homework assignment for the class Aspects of System Administration at Stevens Institute of Technology in the Spring of 2010.
